Invoking: `validate` with `{'patch': '--- a/lib/Parser/JSParserImpl.cpp\n+++ b/lib/Parser/JSParserImpl.cpp\n@@ -525,6 +525,7 @@ Optional<ESTree::Node *> JSParserImpl::parseAssignmentExpression(\n     Param param,\n     AllowTypedArrowFunction allowTypedArrowFunction,\n     CoverTypedParameters coverTypedParameters,\n     ESTree::Node *typeParams) {\n+  CHECK_RECURSION;\n   struct State {\n     SMLoc leftStartLoc = {};\n     Optional<ESTree::Node *> optLeftExpr = llvh::None;'}`
responded: Now I understand the issue better. The problem is that while `parseAssignmentExpression` has protection against deeply nested assignments (up to 30,000), the mutual recursion between `parseAssignmentExpression` and `parseConditionalExpression` can still cause stack overflow because:

1. `parseConditionalExpression` has `CHECK_RECURSION` which limits recursion to `MAX_RECURSION_DEPTH` (128-1024 depending on build)
2. `parseAssignmentExpression` doesn't have `CHECK_RECURSION` at the beginning
3. The mutual recursion can exceed the stack limit before hitting the recursion depth limit

The fix is to add `CHECK_RECURSION` to the beginning of `parseAssignmentExpression` to ensure both functions in the mutual recursion cycle are properly protected.
